page.title: 01North of Trawsfynydd
page.content: A mainly unpopulated rural area, with a nuclear power station dominating it. This is cooled by water from the man-made lake which covers most of this block. The land cover also includes scrub oak, moorland and some afforestation. A small part of the NW is protected land because of a rare species of heathland bush. There is a Roman fort, surmounted by a motte-&-bailey on the NE. It is very poor agricultural land, mainly used for sheep farming. The lake is stocked with trout and provides good fishing, as it also contains coarse fish. It is attractive country visited by tourists in holiday cottages, and a few caravans and tents. There is very little public transport. In spite of the altitude - approximately 750 feet - the weather is generally mild.
